Transferring robotic systems trained or designed in simulation to the real world, known as sim-to-real transfer, presents several significant challenges. These challenges stem primarily from the "reality gap"‚Äîthe discrepancies between the simulated environment and the real world [13]. Understanding and addressing these challenges is crucial for the successful deployment of robotic systems trained in simulation into practical real-world applications. 

Dynamics Mismatch [1]

One major challenge is the mismatch in dynamics between the simulated and real environments. Simulations often rely on simplified models for calculating physical interactions, such as forces and friction, which can differ significantly from real-world conditions [0][1]. For example, factors like actuator imperfections, motor backlash, and variable friction are difficult to precisely replicate in simulation [0]. This discrepancy can lead to poor performance or failure when the trained model is deployed in the real world [2].

Sensor discrepancies can significantly impact the performance of robotic control systems when transitioning from simulation to real-world environments. These discrepancies may include issues such as bias and noise in onboard sensors, as well as partial observability where real-world observations are limited to sensor readings, whereas in simulation, the full dynamical state of the system is available [0]. 

Simulated environments often provide perfect or near-perfect sensor readings, whereas real-world sensors are subject to noise, bias, and jitter [0][8]. The control system in a real robot must handle multiple noisy sensor inputs without overreacting to any single reading, a complexity that simulations do not usually capture [0]. Techniques like pixel-level domain adaptation have been employed to bridge the gap between synthetic and real camera images, improving the robustness of policies trained in simulation [8]. However, pixel-level domain adaptation often requires extensive labeled data for training, and the adapted images might still lack the realism necessary to fully bridge the gap, as they may fail to capture nuances like lighting variations and occlusions present in real-world settings. This can result in the adapted model performing suboptimally once deployed in real-world environments.

Partial observability limits real world observations to sensors readings, whereas in simulation the full dynamical state of the system is available [0]. 

In simulation, the full dynamic state of the system is often available, which is not the case in the real world. Real-world observations are limited to sensor readings, making it difficult to apply the same control strategies used in simulation directly [0]. This partial observability can hinder the system's ability to make informed decisions, compromising stability and performance [3].

Domain Randomization is a technique used to bridge the gap between simulated and real-world environments by randomizing various aspects of the simulation during training to make the learned policies more robust to discrepancies between the simulated and real environments [1]. This method enables the policies to generalize to the dynamics of the real world without any training on the physical system [1]. By incorporating a wide range of conditions in simulation, domain randomization helps in transferring the learned policies to the real world successfully [9]. This approach has shown effectiveness in different robotic tasks, such as object pushing and humanoid robot motion, reducing the reality gap significantly [0]. 

Domain randomization is a technique used to address the reality gap by training models on a wide range of simulated scenarios with varying parameters [1]. This approach helps in developing policies that are robust to differences between the simulation and the real world. However, creating sufficiently varied yet realistic simulations can be challenging and computationally expensive [7]. For example, Tan et al. utilized domain randomization to train quadruped locomotion policies by varying parameters like mass, friction, and motor strengths, which helped in achieving robust transfer to real robots [10]. However, too wide a range of parameter variations can simulate infeasible scenarios, which may confuse the learning process [3]. One effective way to manage this is by starting with narrower distributions that are gradually widened based on the success of the policy in real-world trials [3].

Real-Time Adaptation

Training robotic control policies in simulation environments offers numerous advantages, such as providing an abundant source of data and alleviating certain safety concerns during the training process. However, one significant challenge is transferring these control policies from simulation to the real world, a phenomenon often referred to as the "reality gap" [1]. The discrepancies between the simulated and real-world environments, including model inaccuracies and sensor noise, can impede the performance of the trained policies when deployed in real-world scenarios [8]. Addressing this gap is crucial for effective domain adaptation, where the goal is to ensure that representations and behaviors learned in the simulation are applicable to the real world [2]. Techniques such as dynamics randomization during training have been employed to develop policies that can adapt to varied dynamics, enhancing their robustness when transferred to real-world systems [1]. Consequently, these adaptive policies can perform reliably even when confronted with significant differences between the training and deployment environments, thereby increasing the feasibility of sim-to-real transfer [8]. 



Real-time adaptation of policies from simulation to the real world presents another layer of complexity. Some methods involve adapting simulation randomization using real-world data to better match the simulated environment to real-world conditions [3]. For instance, Clavera et al. demonstrated the effectiveness of this approach by training a robotic arm in simulation and updating the simulation parameters based on real-world feedback, thereby improving the robustness of the policy when deployed in the real world. This iterative process can be effective but requires careful calibration and validation against the real environment [12]. Additionally, the method outlined by Christiano et al. involves training an inverse-dynamics model using real-world data to refine the simulation, thus enhancing the accuracy and effectiveness of transferred policies [2].

Simulations are attractive environments for training agents as they provide an abundant source of data and alleviate certain safety concerns during the training process. But the behaviours developed by agents in simulation are often specific to the characteristics of the simulator. Due to modeling error, strategies that are successful in simulation may not transfer to their real world counterparts[1]. In this paper, we demonstrate a simple method to bridge this ‚Äúreality gap‚Äù. By randomizing the dynamics of the simulator during training, we are able to develop policies that are capable of adapting to very different dynamics, including ones that differ significantly from the dynamics on which the policies were trained. This adaptivity enables the policies to generalize to the dynamics of the real world without any training on the physical system[1]. Our approach is demonstrated on an object pushing task using a robotic arm. Despite being trained exclusively in simulation, our policies are able to maintain a similar level of performance when deployed on a real robot, reliably moving an object to a desired location from random initial configurations[1]. 

We explore the impact of various design decisions and show that the resulting policies are robust to significant calibration error[1]. One of the key assumptions behind these methods is that the different domains share common characteristics such that representations and behaviours learned in one will prove useful for the other[2]. Learning invariant features has emerged as a promising approach of taking advantage of these commonalities, 12. Tzeng et al. and Gupta et al. explored using pairwise constraints to encourage networks to learn similar embeddings for samples from different domains that are labeled as being similar[2]. Daftry et al. applied a similar approach to transfer policies for controlling aerial vehicles to different environments and vehicle models[2]. In the context of RL, adversarial losses have been used to transfer policies between different simulated domains, by encouraging agents to adopt similar behaviours across the various environments[2]. Alternatively, progressive networks have also been used to transfer policies for a robotic arm from simulation to the real world[2]. By reusing features learned in simulation, their method was able to significantly reduce the amount of data needed from the physical system[2]. Christiano et al. transfered policies from simulation to a real robot by training an inverse-dynamics model from real world data[2]. While promising, these methods nonetheless still require data from the target domain during training[2].

Learning continuous control in real world complex environments has seen a wide interest in the past few years and in particular focusing on learning policies in simulators and transferring them to the real world, as we still struggle with finding ways to acquire the necessary amount of experience and data in the real world directly[7]. While there have been recent attempts on learning by collecting large scale data directly on real robots¬†, 2, 3, 4, such an approach still remains challenging as collecting real world data is prohibitively laborious and expensive[7]. Simulators offer several advantages, e.g. they can run faster than real-time and allow for acquiring large diversity of training data[7]. However, due to the imprecise simulation models and lack of high fidelity replication of real world scenes, policies learned in simulations often cannot be directly applied on real world systems, a phenomenon also known as the reality gap¬†[7]. In this work, we focus on closing the reality gap by learning policies on distributions of simulated scenarios that are optimized for a better policy transfer[7].

Exploring and learning in real-world settings can pose safety risks to both the robot and its surroundings [13]. Simulations provide a safer environment for training, but transferring those policies without ensuring they are safe for real-world deployment can lead to dangerous outcomes [13]. Several techniques aim to mitigate these risks, including:

**Safe Reinforcement Learning:** Incorporates safety constraints into the learning process to prevent the agent from taking potentially dangerous actions [14].

**Shielding:** A technique where a safety layer is added to the control policy to override any unsafe actions proposed by the learned policy [14].

**Simulated Safety Training:** Uses simulation to train and validate the policy under a variety of potentially hazardous scenarios, ensuring that the learned policies are robust and safe before real-world deployment [13].

Computational constraints have a significant impact on the effectiveness of sim-to-real transfer for robotic control policies. One major issue is the reality gap, where policies trained in simulation degrade in performance when applied to real-world systems due to inaccuracies in the simulation model [11]. Moreover, achieving high-fidelity simulations that accurately replicate real-world physics can be computationally expensive, which often leads to the use of less accurate simulators that may hinder effective sim-to-real transfer [11]. Additionally, transferring policies from simulation to reality is challenging due to discrepancies in sensor inputs and dynamics between simulated and real environments [8]. Various techniques, such as domain randomization and simulation randomization, have been proposed to bridge the reality gap and facilitate successful policy transfer [9]. However, these methods require careful calibration and extensive computational resources to adapt simulation parameters [1].

Highly accurate simulations are computationally expensive, which can limit their practicality. A balance must be struck between the accuracy of the simulation and computational efficiency [11]. One approach is to use an initially less accurate but computationally inexpensive simulation to train baseline policies and then gradually increase the accuracy as needed while incorporating real-world data into the simulation model. This staged approach can help in maintaining computational efficiency without excessively compromising the realism needed to bridge the reality gap. Additionally, leveraging cloud computing and parallelization can distribute the computational load, allowing more complex simulations to run without excessive local resource consumption.

### Real-World Data Collection and Fine-Tuning

Collecting real-world data for fine-tuning and validating models is often laborious and expensive. While simulators offer the advantage of generating large and varied datasets quickly, real-world validation remains essential to ensure the robustness and reliability of the trained models [7]. Methods to address this include:

**Progressive Refinement:** Begin with simulation-trained models and incrementally update them with real-world data to improve accuracy and robustness. This method can help in identifying the key areas where the simulation diverges from reality and make targeted adjustments [3]. 

**Active Learning:** Involves selectively sampling the most informative data points from the real world to maximize learning efficiency. This reduces the amount of real-world data needed by focusing efforts on the most critical areas for improvement [14]. 

**Transfer Learning:** Using pre-trained models from similar tasks or domains and fine-tuning them with real-world data specific to the new task. This approach leverages existing knowledge to reduce the amount of new data required [2] and speeds up the adaptation process [2]. 

### Ensemble Methods and Hybrid Models

In addition to the techniques mentioned, ensemble methods and hybrid models have shown promise in addressing the sim-to-real gap. Ensemble methods involve training multiple models and combining their outputs to improve robustness and accuracy when transferring to the real world. These methods can help mitigate the errors of individual models and provide more reliable performance. Hybrid models, on the other hand, combine data-driven approaches with traditional model-based methods to leverage the strengths of both. For instance, a hybrid approach might use a physics-based model to provide a rough estimate of the system's behavior, while a data-driven model refines the predictions based on real-world observations. This can enhance the model's ability to generalize from simulation to reality and reduce the dependency on large amounts of real-world data [9].

The control system must respond to multiple noisy sensor inputs simultaneously while avoiding over-reacting to any single sensor reading [0]. Smoothing techniques applied to reduce the sensor spikes in general come at the cost of responsiveness to the sensor inputs which is vital to maintaining stability [0]. Partial observability limits real world observations to sensors readings, whereas in simulation the full dynamical state of the system is available [0]. Such limitations make domain adaptation from a simulation environment to a real world environment difficult [7]. 

In summary, several challenges arise when attempting to transfer robotic systems trained in simulation to the real world, including dynamics mismatches [1], sensor discrepancies [8], partial observability [0], domain randomization [7], real-time adaptation, safety concerns [13], computational constraints [14], and the need for real-world data collection and fine-tuning [12]. Additionally, ensemble methods and hybrid models offer promising avenues to further bridge the reality gap [2]. Addressing these challenges requires a combination of robust simulation techniques [3], real-world data integration [7], continuous adaptation [3], and innovative modeling approaches to ensure successful and safe deployment [13].

Commonsense Reasoning and Code Understanding [1]. 

One of the primary benefits of using LLMs in robot planning tasks is their ability to leverage commonsense reasoning and code understanding to generate executable plans directly as programs. For instance, the ProgPrompt framework constructs prompts that include situational understanding of the world and robot capabilities, thereby enabling LLMs to generate situated and executable plans that generalize to new scenes, agents, and tasks, including real-robot deployments. ProgPrompt demonstrated state-of-the-art success rates in VirtualHome household tasks and successful deployment on a physical robot arm for tabletop tasks [1]. ProgPrompt excels in scenarios that require flexible adaptation to varying environments and robot capabilities, making it suitable for both virtual and physical tasks.

Feasibility and Multimodal Feedback [3].

Research has shown that LLMs, such as GPT-3, ChatGPT, and CodeX, encode an extensive amount of common sense, making them suitable for robot task planning in various domains. For example, the SayCan framework takes advantage of LLMs by translating abstract service requests into feasible action sequences through the use of affordance functions, which assess action feasibility based on the current scene [2]. SayCan is particularly effective in household task domains where the feasibility of actions must be rigorously assessed to ensure successful execution. Similarly, Inner Monologue represents another significant advancement by integrating multimodal feedback from the environment, including visual and sensory inputs, to create more reliable and contextually aware task plans [3]. Inner Monologue is ideal for applications requiring real-time adaptation to environmental changes, leveraging its robust multimodal integration.

Large-Scale and Complex Environments [6]. 

Furthermore, LLMs have shown promise in complex and large-scale environments. SayPlan utilizes 3D scene graphs to ground task plans in multi-floor and multi-room environments. This involves hierarchical semantic search and iterative replanning, which refine initial plans based on feedback from a scene graph simulator, ensuring feasibility and avoiding planning failures. SayPlan was evaluated on environments spanning up to 3 floors and 36 rooms with 140 assets and objects, demonstrating its capability to ground large-scale, long-horizon task plans for a mobile manipulator robot [11]. SayPlan is most effective in large, structured environments where detailed spatial information is crucial for successful task execution.

Multi-Robot Collaboration[8].

LLMs are not only effective for single-robot task planning but also exhibit potential in multi-robot scenarios. The SMART-LLM framework converts high-level task instructions into multi-robot task plans through programmatic LLM prompts for task decomposition, coalition formation, and task allocation [8]. Experiments have shown that such frameworks can handle task instructions of varying complexities, generalizing seamlessly to new environments and robot types, thereby streamlining the transition from simulation to real-world applications [9]. Additionally, RoCo introduces a dialectic approach where multiple robots equipped with LLMs collaborate, generate sub-task plans, and refine their strategies using feedback from the environment. RoCo achieved high success rates across various tasks in the RoCoBench benchmark [12]. SMART-LLM and RoCo are particularly beneficial in scenarios requiring coordinated multi-robot operations, with SMART-LLM focusing on task allocation efficiency and RoCo emphasizing collaborative planning and real-time strategy refinement.


Adaptive and Corrective Mechanisms [10].


The effectiveness of LLMs in robot planning is further enhanced through adaptive and corrective mechanisms. For instance, the KNOWNO framework aligns the uncertainty of LLM-based planners with real-world task environments using a combination of few-shot prompting and Bayesian inference, which allows robots to perform multi-step planning tasks more autonomously and efficiently [7]. Similarly, CoPAL employs a replanning strategy that adjusts for physically grounded, logical, and semantic errors, enhancing the executability and correctness of generated plans [10]. KNOWNO and CoPAL are essential in high-stakes environments where planning accuracy and adaptability to unforeseen conditions are paramount.

Evaluating variable type inference for decompiled binaries is an essential domain within software reverse engineering, aimed at recovering semantic information lost during compilation and stripping processes [8]. Such efforts are critical for understanding and analyzing closed-source programs, improving decompiler outputs [2], and enhancing software security [8]. Several datasets have been employed for training and evaluating models in this context, each with unique characteristics and emphases [4]. 

Datasets with a Python Focus [3]. 

**ManyTypes4Py Dataset**: This large Python dataset includes partial type annotations for functions and variables and aims to serve as a benchmark for ML-based type inference models. It uses abstract syntax trees (ASTs) for static analysis, providing a comprehensive resource for training and evaluating ML models in type inference [3][9][14]. Metrics used for evaluation include the accuracy of type predictions and the model's ability to generalize to unseen code samples. The ManyTypes4Py dataset is utilized in experiments to test models like Type4Py, which benefits from the extensive annotations and AST analysis to improve type prediction accuracy. However, its limitation lies in its focus on Python, potentially limiting its applicability to other programming languages.

**TYPEPY Dataset**: Featured in the evaluation of PYInfer, this dataset comprises 500 of the most common types derived from analyzing a large corpus of Python code. The dataset is rich in annotations and has been used to evaluate the effectiveness of type inference models, especially in light of the uneven distribution of real-world variable usage [7]. The evaluation typically involves metrics such as precision, recall, and the overall accuracy of predicted type annotations. A notable limitation is its focus on common types, which might not encompass the full range of types encountered in practice.


### Datasets for General Binary Code Analysis

Code analysis is a powerful way to eliminate vulnerabilities. Closed-source programs lack crucial information vital for code analysis because that information is stripped on compilation to achieve smaller executable size [0]. Restoration has always been a challenge for experts. Variable type information is fundamental in this process because it helps to provide a perspective on program semantic [1]. In this paper, we present an efficient approach for inferring types, and we overcome the challenge of scattered information provided by static analysis on stripped binaries. We discover that neighboring instructions are likely to operate the same type of variables, which are leveraged to enrich the features that we rely on. Therefore, we implement a system called CATI, which locates variables from stripped binaries and infers 19 types from variables. Experiments show that it infers variable type with 71.2% accuracy on unseen binaries. Meanwhile, it takes approximately 6 seconds to process a typical binary.


**DIRT Dataset**: This dataset includes debug information that often changes the layout of the code as the decompiler adds structures and syntax for accessing them. The DIRT dataset is noteworthy for its focus on recovering types from C binaries [12]. TypeMiner is an example of work utilizing this dataset. TypeMiner employs simpler machine learning algorithms on a dataset consisting of 23,482 variables and 17 primitive types, aiming to recover types from stripped binaries. The limitation here is the relatively small size and the use of simpler machine learning algorithms, which may not capture the full complexity of types in more diverse datasets.

**EKLAVYA Dataset**: Although not explicitly named, this dataset includes real open-source applications and synthetic programs. It has been employed to improve type information inferred by decompilers through supervised machine learning techniques [8]. EKLAVYA‚Äôs dataset facilitated the association of binary patterns with high-level constructs, significantly enhancing the accuracy of function return type predictions. Specific applications include training classification models that predict function return types with an F1-measure of 79.1%, compared to a 30% F1-measure from existing decompilers. The limitation here is the dataset's focus on specific compiler settings and the potential lack of generalizability to other compilers or languages.

**CAPYBARA Dataset**: Introduced alongside the BinT5 model, this dataset supports the summarization of decompiled binaries. CAPYBARA includes both mined and synthetic data, designed to train and evaluate models like BinT5 in a novel automatic binary code summarization task [4][6]. The evaluation metrics often involve the quality of the generated summaries, assessed through measures like BLEU scores that compare the generated text to reference summaries. In practice, CAPYBARA is used to benchmark the BinT5 model's ability to generate coherent and accurate summaries of decompiled code, demonstrating the model's effectiveness and highlighting challenges in the summarization task. The limitation here is the complexity of aligning decompiled and source code accurately for effective training.

Datasets for Variable Naming and Semantic Recovery [2].

**DIRE Dataset**: Used in the development of the Decompiled Identifier Renaming Engine (DIRE), this dataset consists of 164,632 unique x86-64 binaries generated from C projects mined from GitHub. It serves to predict variable names identical to those in the original source code, reflecting its utility in improving code understandability and facilitating semantic recovery [2][13]. Evaluation metrics for this dataset include the accuracy of variable name predictions and the ability to maintain semantic consistency with the original source code. In DIRE, this dataset allows for training and testing naming models, which achieve a prediction accuracy of up to 74.3%, demonstrating the technique's efficiency in renaming variables in decompiled code. However, its limitation is the potential overfitting to specific patterns in the GitHub-mined dataset and the challenge of maintaining high accuracy across diverse coding practices.

Comparison of Datasets

 - **Size**: The size of datasets varies significantly. The ManyTypes4Py dataset includes more than 869K type annotations from 5,382 Python projects, making it one of the largest available [9]. On the other hand, the TYPEPY dataset, used in PYInfer, focuses on 500 common types, likely representing smaller but more targeted data [7]. 

 - **Complexity**: DIRT and EKLAVYA datasets include debug information and are used for training simpler machine learning models, implying a moderate level of complexity [12]. In contrast, ManyTypes4Py and CAPYBARA datasets support more advanced models like transformers (BinT5), indicating higher complexity [4]. 

The type of annotations provided also differs. ManyTypes4Py and TYPEPY offer extensive type annotations extracted from ASTs, aiding in detailed type inference tasks [3]. DIRT and EKLAVYA primarily focus on lower-level binary patterns and function return types [8]. CAPYBARA provides annotated summaries [4], while DIRE focuses on variable names, highlighting distinct semantic recovery purposes [2]. 

Recent advancements in machine learning have significantly improved the ability to infer variable types from binary code [0]. Techniques such as decompilation can help recover much of the information lost during compilation, including structure and type information [2]. However, challenges remain in reconstructing semantically meaningful variable names, which are important for code understandability [2]. To address these, probabilistic techniques have been developed to recover variable names by utilizing both lexical and structural information [2]. Furthermore, supervised machine learning approaches have been employed to enhance type information inferred by decompilers, achieving higher accuracy than traditional methods [5]. These advancements highlight the ongoing progress in code analysis and the potential for machine learning to further enhance reverse engineering practices [5]. 

Recent advancements in the field of variable type inference for decompiled binaries have significantly benefited from the development of these datasets [4]. There is a clear trend towards using more sophisticated machine learning models, particularly deep learning techniques, to handle the complexity of code decompilation and type inference [5]. 

One notable advancement is the use of transformer-based models, such as BinT5, which leverage the CAPYBARA dataset to achieve impressive results in binary code summarization tasks [4]. These models demonstrate the potential of transfer learning and pre-trained language models in enhancing the quality and accuracy of decompiled code summaries [4].

Moreover, the focus on creating extensive and diverse datasets, such as ManyTypes4Py, has enabled the training of more robust and generalizable models [9]. The inclusion of contextual semantic information and comprehensive annotations has proven to be crucial in improving the performance of type inference models across different programming languages and coding styles [7].

Another trend is the integration of probabilistic and graph-based models, as seen in the DIRE project, which combines lexical and structural information to improve the recovery of meaningful variable names [2]. This approach highlights the importance of multi-faceted data representations in tackling the challenges of decompilation. 

Overall, the field is moving towards leveraging larger, more diverse datasets and advanced machine learning techniques to enhance the accuracy and usability of decompiled code [5]. These advancements underline the importance of continuous dataset development and model innovation to address the evolving challenges in software reverse engineering [5].

Post-quantum cryptographic (PQC) algorithms such as Kyber and Dilithium are designed to be resilient against quantum computing attacks, setting them apart from traditional cryptographic methods like RSA and ECC [1]. However, this quantum resistance comes with performance and energy cost trade-offs [0]. 

Performance Comparison: RSA and ECC, although widely used, are vulnerable to quantum attacks because they are based on mathematical problems that quantum computers can solve efficiently. Dilithium and Kyber, on the other hand, were specifically designed to resist such attacks and provide robust security in anticipation of quantum computing advances. [1] However, there are also performance trade-offs to consider. Regarding computational speed, RSA and ECC generally outperform PQC-based solutions such as Dilithium and Kyber. [1] 


Kyber and Dilithium, like many PQC algorithms, generally exhibit slower computational performance compared to traditional cryptographic methods such as RSA and ECC. For instance, while RSA and ECC algorithms are optimized and widely used, they are vulnerable to quantum attacks [1]. Kyber and Dilithium, on the other hand, are designed to resist these attacks but may require more computational resources, resulting in slower performance, particularly in resource-constrained environments [1][2]. Specifically, Dilithium can be more computationally expensive for signature generation compared to RSA-4096 [0]. On more powerful devices such as a Raspberry Pi 4, Kyber's key encapsulation and decapsulation functions show comparable efficiency, requiring only 100-300 microseconds, although they may still lag behind traditional methods in some specific scenarios [0].

Energy consumption is a significant consideration in the deployment of post-quantum cryptography (PQC) schemes. Studies have shown that lattice-based cryptographic algorithms, such as Kyber and Dilithium, exhibit varying levels of energy efficiency. For example, evaluations of Dilithium and Falcon reveal that their power consumption is comparable to that of RSA-4096, a commonly used pre-quantum cryptographic algorithm [0]. Research also indicates that while lattice-based key encapsulation mechanisms (KEMs) such as Kyber may have favorable energy consumption profiles compared to traditional schemes like ECDH, this advantage is partly offset by the increased bandwidth requirements associated with PQC [6]. Additionally, the integration of hardware accelerators and instruction set extensions tailored for lattice-based PQC can significantly reduce energy consumption and enhance performance, making these schemes more viable for resource-constrained environments [12]. The careful selection and combination of post-quantum digital signature algorithms and KEMs, such as employing Dilithium for client-side certificates and Kyber for key exchanges, can optimize the trade-off between energy consumption, latency, and bandwidth in low-power IoT applications [4].
The energy consumption of PQC algorithms is another significant concern, especially for applications in low-power environments such as the Internet of Things (IoT). Studies have shown that lattice-based schemes like Kyber and Dilithium have energy costs that can be on par with or even exceed traditional cryptographic methods. For instance, on devices such as the Raspberry Pi 3 and 4, lattice-based KEMs like Kyber and NTRU have shown faster key exchanges than ECDH, but signature schemes like Dilithium still lag behind ECDSA in terms of energy efficiency [6]. In signature-based authentication scenarios, the power consumption of Dilithium and Falcon matches that of RSA-4096, demonstrating significant energy demands [0]. This suggests that while lattice-based PQC algorithms are feasible for certain applications, their higher computational and energy demands could be challenging for energy-constrained devices.

**Key Size, Bandwidth, and Storage:**
Another critical factor is the key size associated with PQC algorithms. Compared to RSA and ECC, PQC algorithms typically have larger key sizes, which impacts storage and bandwidth requirements. Kyber, for instance, has a key size ranging from 800 bytes to 1.5 kilobytes, which is smaller than the 2-kilobyte key size of RSA but still larger than those of ECC [2][9]. Larger key sizes can increase the bandwidth requirements and affect the overall performance, especially in networked environments [6]. For comparison, ECC typically operates with much smaller key sizes. For example, ECC-256 has a key size of just 256 bits, providing efficient transmission and storage benefits [1]. These increased key sizes in PQC translate to higher transmission overhead and storage demands, which can be particularly burdensome in constrained environments like IoT devices.

Practical Applications and Case Studies: Kyber (and lattice-based cryptography in general) can run efficiently even on constrained devices. For instance, Kyber768 can operate within just 13 kilobytes of RAM, although this process takes approximately 9.8 seconds with the aid of a cryptography co-processor. On more powerful devices like the Raspberry Pi 4, core functions of Kyber can be computed in 100-300 microseconds [0]. Lattice-based cryptography like Kyber and SABER have shown promising performance metrics, outperforming traditional schemes like RSA in certain conditions, especially when assisted by hardware acceleration [1]. Moreover, the integration of Kyber in practical applications is facilitated by its relatively small key sizes, which range from 800 bytes to 1.5 kilobytes, in contrast to the 2-kilobyte key size required for RSA [2]. Additionally, the power consumption of lattice-based signatures such as Dilithium and Falcon is comparable to RSA-4096, making them suitable for applications where energy efficiency is critical [1]. Recent advances also highlight that lattice-based schemes like Kyber can achieve impressive throughput performance, with optimizations allowing for thousands of operations per second on devices equipped with dedicated hardware like small GPUs [7]. 
Practical implementations of Kyber and Dilithium have already begun, highlighting their feasibility and potential challenges. For example, Cloudflare has integrated CRYSTALS-Kyber into its Reusable Cryptographic Library, and Amazon has introduced a hybrid Kyber mode, underscoring the industry's move towards adopting PQC [2]. Additionally, a post-quantum TLS protocol using Kyber-SPHINCS+ cipher suite demonstrated reasonable feasibility for secure communication, though it introduced significant latency and memory usage, especially due to the SPHINCS+ signatures [5]. Another case study involved running Kyber-512 on a Jetson Nano using GPU acceleration, where it achieved a throughput performance of 1,345 key encapsulations per second, illustrating the benefits of hardware acceleration for PQC [7].


**Future Hardware Optimizations:** The efficient implementation of post-quantum cryptography (PQC) systems on various hardware platforms is crucial for their practical application. For instance, Kyber and Dilithium operations can achieve significant performance improvements through hardware acceleration [12]. Recent approaches utilize hardware/software co-design to integrate powerful accelerators into processors, enhancing the performance of lattice-based PQC algorithms while maintaining low silicon area overhead [12]. Moreover, advancements in GPU acceleration have demonstrated substantial performance boosts for cryptographic operations, such as key encapsulation and decapsulation, on embedded devices like the Jetson Nano [7]. The application of custom countermeasures against side-channel and fault injection attacks also contributes to the secure and efficient deployment of PQC systems on hardware [14]. These optimizations are critical as they address the latency and energy consumption challenges posed by PQC, especially in constrained environments like IoT devices [4].

Future advancements in hardware optimizations can mitigate some of the performance and energy costs associated with PQC algorithms. For instance, hardware acceleration using GPUs or FPGA implementations have shown promising results in improving the performance of PQC algorithms. A study demonstrated that GPU acceleration on devices like the Jetson Nano significantly enhances the throughput performance of Kyber-512, achieving 1,345 key encapsulations per second and 918 key decapsulations per second [7]. Similarly, integrating specialized hardware accelerators and optimizing the instruction set architecture (ISA) for specific lattice-based operations can also yield substantial performance gains. The RISQ-V architecture, which includes tightly coupled hardware accelerators for Kyber and Saber, has shown up to 9.6 times speedup for Kyber and significant reductions in energy consumption [12]. Additionally, the development of unified architectures like KaLi, which efficiently handle multiple PQC operations, represents a step towards optimizing latency and resource utilization for PQC implementations [10].

**Systematic Evaluation of Future Hardware Optimizations:**
To accelerate linear performance bottlenecks, we developed a generic Number Theoretic Transform (NTT) multiplier, which, in contrast to previously published accelerators, is also efficient and suitable for schemes not based on NTT. For the critical non-linear operations, masked HW accelerators were developed, allowing a secure execution using RISC-V instruction set extensions [8]. With the proposed design, we achieved a cycle count of K:214k/E:298k/D:313k for Kyber and K:233k/E:312k/D:351k for Saber with NIST Level III parameter sets [8]. It is shown that by utilizing GPU acceleration on the Jetson Nano, Kyber-512 can achieve a throughput performance of 1,345 key encapsulations per second and 918 key decapsulations per second [7].

To systematically evaluate the impact of future hardware optimizations, a multi-faceted approach can be adopted. Firstly, benchmarking diverse hardware platforms with and without hardware acceleration for PQC operations provides clear performance comparisons. This can be done by evaluating key metrics such as computation time, energy consumption, and thermal footprint across various devices under identical test conditions. Secondly, establishing standardized testbeds and utilizing public repositories of performance data can help track improvements over time. For example, the pqm4 library for ARM Cortex-M4-based microcontrollers and the liboqs library for Raspberry Pi 3 Model B Plus [14] provide valuable data for such analyses. Thirdly, leveraging simulation frameworks to predict performance improvements from theoretical hardware modifications can guide practical implementations. These combined strategies ensure a comprehensive understanding of how future hardware developments will influence the efficiency of PQC algorithms. 

In summary, while post-quantum cryptographic algorithms such as Kyber and Dilithium provide robust security against quantum attacks [1], they currently exhibit higher performance and energy costs compared to traditional methods [0]. However, ongoing advancements in hardware optimization and specialized accelerators hold promise for bridging this performance gap and making PQC more feasible for a broader range of applications [12].

Effectively measuring software engineering process improvements in real-world settings requires a comprehensive approach that incorporates multiple methodologies and frameworks. This multi-faceted strategy ensures that improvements are not only quantitatively assessed but also qualitatively understood, providing a holistic view of their impact [0].

One primary method to measure process improvements is through **surveys and feedback** from employees and customers, as these stakeholders are directly impacted by the changes. Surveys can capture qualitative data on how the changes have affected day-to-day operations, team dynamics, and overall satisfaction. Pettersson's approach integrates expert opinions to compare the improved process with the previous state, offering insights into the perceived effectiveness of the changes introduced [0]. For example, at Ericsson, employee feedback was used to assess process learning and commitment, providing detailed insights into how these changes were experienced on the ground [5]. However, a potential limitation of this method is that it may be subject to bias or unrepresentative sampling if not designed and administered properly.

Another critical methodology is **cost-benefit analysis**, which evaluates the financial impact of the improvements. This analysis considers not just the direct costs and savings but also indirect and intangible benefits like improved customer satisfaction and employee morale. Activities such as Activity Based Costing help to relate specific activities to their costs, aiding in a more precise estimation of the financial impact [1]. For instance, a software company implemented a cost-benefit analysis to evaluate training programs designed to improve employee motivation, resulting in tangible estimates of the benefits realized through enhanced productivity and morale. Nevertheless, accurately quantifying indirect benefits can be challenging and often requires consensus among stakeholders on the valuation methods used.

**Statistical techniques** are also essential in measuring the effectiveness of process improvements. Techniques such as multiple regression, rank correlation, and chi-square tests of independence can provide quantifiable evidence of process improvements over time [2]. These methods help in identifying trends and correlations that might not be immediately apparent, thereby providing a more objective measure of effectiveness. However, it is crucial to use these methods with caution as relying on a single statistical technique may not fully capture the impact of the changes and could lead to incorrect conclusions [2]. For example, a longitudinal field study at a major software firm analyzed over 7,000 software defects and found significant reductions in high-severity defects with higher levels of process improvement, especially in complex systems [8]. A limitation of statistical techniques is that they require rigorous data collection protocols to ensure validity and reliability.

The **Goal‚ÄìQuestion‚ÄìMetric (GQM) approach** offers a structured way to measure improvements by linking organizational goals to specific questions and metrics [5]. This approach was successfully employed in a longitudinal study at Ericsson, where metrics were designed to measure process use, commitment, learning, and improvement. Such a framework ensures that the measurement activities are aligned with the strategic objectives of the organization and provide actionable insights into the effectiveness of the process improvements. However, defining appropriate goals and metrics can be complex and requires in-depth understanding of both the process and organizational context.

**Longitudinal field studies** also provide valuable insights into the impact of process improvements. For example, a study analyzing 7,545 software defects found that higher levels of software process improvement significantly reduced the likelihood of high-severity defects, especially in large or complex systems [8]. This empirical evidence underscores the long-term benefits of sustained process improvement efforts and their impact on software quality. One challenge of longitudinal studies is that they require extended time frames and consistent data collection efforts, which can be resource-intensive.

**Addressing confounding factors** is critical for the validity of any measurement strategy. Many studies fail to consider confounding factors that might influence the outcomes of process improvements [3]. To practically identify and control these factors, one approach is to integrate methods such as control groups, randomization, and longitudinal data collection. For instance, confounding factors might include changes in team composition, shifts in project scope, or external economic conditions. By isolating the variables through careful study design and employing statistical controls, researchers can better attribute observed changes to the process improvements themselves. For example, Ericsson used such methods to isolate the effects of specific process changes from other variables, providing a clearer picture of the impact of their process improvements [5]. A limitation here is that some confounding factors might be difficult to identify or control completely.

An emerging trend in measuring software engineering process improvements is the use of **automated measurement-based feedback systems**. These systems integrate measurement and process technologies to provide real-time feedback to developers and maintainers about their work. This automation can significantly enhance the accuracy and usefulness of measurements by offering continuous, on-line data about the tasks being performed. For example, a process-centered software engineering environment developed for measurement-based feedback offers detailed information about the tasks expected based on an integrated set of measurement and process views [7]. This kind of real-time feedback can help software professionals gain better control over their projects and improve their practices more dynamically. However, the implementation of automated systems requires initial investments in technology and the development of models suited to the specific workflow of the organization, which may pose a challenge for some companies.

In summary, effectively measuring software engineering process improvements in real-world settings involves a combination of qualitative and quantitative methods, including surveys [0], cost-benefit analysis [1], statistical techniques [2], the GQM approach [5], longitudinal field studies [8], consideration of confounding factors [3], and leveraging emerging trends like automated feedback systems [7]. This multi-layered approach provides a robust framework for evaluating the true impact of process improvements on both the organization and its stakeholders while considering the potential limitations and challenges of each methodology.

Recent techniques for text watermarking have demonstrated significant advancements in robustness and effectiveness, particularly against various forms of paraphrasing and editing attacks [2]. These techniques can be broadly classified into several categories: context-aware lexical substitution [7], adversarial watermark embedding [1], error correction-based methods [5], and semantic-based watermarking [13]. Each of these techniques has its strengths and vulnerabilities with respect to different types of transformations and attacks [7]. 

**1. Context-Aware Lexical Substitution** [7]. 
The use of context-aware lexical substitution in text watermarking addresses the limitations of previous methods that neglected the context of target words. For instance, Yang et al. (2022) introduced a BERT-based infill model that generates contextually appropriate lexical substitutions, which are then used to embed watermarks [7]. Such methods ensure that the semantic integrity of the text is maintained while embedding the watermark. This approach is robust against simple synonym replacement and some forms of paraphrasing attacks. However, its effectiveness can be compromised when dealing with more sophisticated paraphrasing techniques that significantly alter sentence structure or semantic meaning without affecting individual words.

**2. Adversarial Watermarking:** [1] 
The Adversarial Watermarking Transformer (AWT) leverages adversarial training to hide data in text through word substitutions that are contextually appropriate and minimally intrusive [1]. AWT's robustness comes from its ability to learn watermark patterns without ground truth, making it resilient against various forms of attacks, including paraphrasing and editing. However, adversarial techniques may struggle with transformations that drastically change the text's structure or introduce significant semantic shifts, such as extensive rewriting by powerful language models like GPT-3 [1].

**Error Correction-Based Methods:** This represents the first LLM multi-bit watermarking scheme that provides a provable robustness bound for every generated sentence. Here we use edit distance (Levenshtein distance) to measure the attacker‚Äôs ability to manipulate watermarked text. The edit distance between two strings is defined as the minimum number of operations (insertion, deletion, or substitution of a token) required to transform one string into the other.[5] 
Error correction codes (ECC) have been employed to enhance the robustness of text watermarks. An example of this is the use of ECC to encode multi-bit watermarks, which ensures that minor edits to the text do not affect the embedded message [12]. This method is particularly robust against insertion, deletion, and substitution attacks, as even if some bits are altered, the original message can still be decoded correctly. Despite its robustness, this technique may falter under extensive editing or paraphrasing attacks that exceed the error correction threshold, leading to potential failures in recovering the original watermark.

**4. Semantic-Based Watermarking:** [13]
Semantic-based watermarking techniques, such as those using presuppositions, leverage natural language semantic structures to embed watermarks. These methods introduce subtle changes in information that are less noticeable and resilient against common transformations like passivization, topicalization, and extraposition [13]. The resilience of these methods to various syntactic transformations makes them highly robust. However, they may be vulnerable to sophisticated paraphrasing attacks that deeply understand and alter the semantics of the text.

**Transformations and Attacks:** [7]

**Robust Against:** [2]
- **Paraphrasing Attacks:** Techniques like the use of error correction codes and context-aware lexical substitution show increased robustness against paraphrasing attacks from models such as GPT-3 or BART [2][8].
- **Editing Attacks:** Error correction-based methods and semantic-based watermarking are robust against common editing attacks, including token insertion, deletion, and substitution [5][10].
- **Rewrite Attacks:** Methods that do not rely on token order, such as those proposed by Zhao et al. (2023a), exhibit robustness against rewrite attacks that disrupt token sequences but fail to replace all tokens [0].

Not Robust Against: [5]
- **Advanced Paraphrasing:** While recent methods have shown improvements, extensive paraphrasing that significantly alters text structure and semantic content can still pose challenges. Advanced paraphrasing techniques using models with high diversity, such as DIPPER-2, can effectively remove watermarks [2].
- **Semantic Shifts:** Transformations that introduce substantial semantic changes to the text, beyond simple lexical substitutions, can compromise many watermarking techniques. While techniques like semantic-based watermarking aim to address this, they are not foolproof against sophisticated semantic alterations [14].

In summary, recent text watermarking techniques exhibit varying degrees of robustness against different types of transformations and attacks. While methods like context-aware lexical substitution and error correction codes offer enhanced robustness against paraphrasing and editing attacks [7][12], challenges remain in addressing advanced paraphrasing and semantic shifts. Continuous research and development are necessary to further improve the resilience of watermarking methods in the face of evolving attack strategies.

Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) methods are evaluated using a variety of datasets that capture different environments, sensor configurations, and levels of complexity [0]. The choice of dataset significantly impacts the evaluation outcomes, emphasizing different aspects of SLAM performance [3]. Below, we discuss several commonly used datasets in the SLAM community. 

Visual SLAM Datasets [0][1][3][7][10]. 

 **TUM RGB-D** [2]: 
   The TUM RGB-D dataset is widely used for evaluating visual SLAM systems, particularly those using RGB-D sensors. This dataset provides indoor scene sequences recorded using a Microsoft Kinect camera at 30Hz, with a resolution of 640x480 pixels [0][2][7]. It includes ground truth camera poses captured by an external motion capture system, making it suitable for evaluating both localization and mapping accuracy. The dataset is extensively used to benchmark systems like ORB-SLAM and LSD-SLAM, thanks to its diverse indoor environments and high-quality ground-truth data [2]. One unique feature is its focus on different types of motion, such as sitting and walking, which help in testing SLAM performance under various dynamic conditions [7].

2. **KITTI**[3]:
   The KITTI dataset is primarily used for evaluating visual and LiDAR-based SLAM methods. Collected using a car equipped with high-resolution stereo cameras and a 3D LiDAR, KITTI includes urban and highway driving scenarios. It offers synchronized data from GPS/IMU systems, which provides ground-truth poses for evaluating SLAM accuracy in outdoor environments [1][3]. This dataset is critical for developing and testing SLAM algorithms intended for autonomous driving applications due to its realistic driving scenarios and comprehensive sensor data [1].

### Visual-Inertial SLAM Datasets[3]



3. **EuRoC MAV** [0]. 
   The EuRoC MAV dataset is designed for evaluating visual-inertial SLAM approaches. It features synchronized and calibrated stereo camera images and IMU data collected from a Micro Aerial Vehicle (MAV) flying in both indoor and industrial environments. The dataset provides high-resolution images (752x480) and IMU measurements at 200Hz, along with accurate ground truth from a laser tracker system [1]. This dataset is particularly beneficial for testing algorithms that integrate visual and inertial data for robust localization in dynamic and challenging conditions [0][1]. An additional feature that sets EuRoC MAV apart is its use of MAVs, which introduces the added challenge of 3D flight dynamics [1].

4. **TUM VI**: [1] 
   The TUM Visual-Inertial dataset (TUM VI) extends the capabilities of the TUM RGB-D dataset by including visual and IMU data. It captures a variety of indoor and outdoor scenes with long sequences, synchronized camera images (1024x1024 resolution), and IMU measurements [1]. This dataset allows the evaluation of visual-inertial SLAM systems across diverse scenarios, providing a more comprehensive benchmark for algorithms that utilize both types of data [1]. The dataset's variety in scene types and longer sequence lengths offer extensive challenges for evaluating SLAM algorithms in more realistic, continuous operation scenarios [1].

Multi-Sensor and Specialized SLAM Datasets[0][1][3]. 

5. **OpenLORIS-Scene** [4]:
   The OpenLORIS-Scene dataset focuses on lifelong SLAM and includes data collected in dynamic environments affected by day-night changes, moving people, and varying viewpoints. It integrates RGB-D, IMU, and odometry data, providing a comprehensive testbed for evaluating the robustness and accuracy of SLAM systems over extended periods and in real-world scenarios [0][4]. This dataset aims to push the boundaries of SLAM algorithms by introducing high-level scene understanding capabilities and testing them under continuous operation with changing conditions [4]. The dataset's focus on real-world deployment scenarios for service robots highlights its uniqueness and importance in SLAM research [4].

This dataset's high accuracy and challenging environments make it suitable for testing SLAM algorithms for industrial applications where precision is paramount [5][6]. Additionally, the dataset's ability to simulate real-world construction and industrial conditions makes it an invaluable resource for robust SLAM evaluations [5].

Several practically relevant properties and classes of \( k \)-node subgraphs in graphs that can be counted faster than cubic time have been identified in recent research to address the deficiencies of previous algorithms, particularly for sparse graphs [1]. These properties leverage various graph parameters, such as degeneracy and tree decomposition, to optimize subgraph counting algorithms [2]. 

 **1. Degeneracy**[^1].

Degeneracy is a measure of graph sparsity and indicates the smallest number \( d \) such that every subgraph of the graph has a vertex with degree at most \( d \). Utilizing degeneracy, pattern graphs can be counted more efficiently. For instance, if a graph \( G \) has degeneracy \( d \), and a pattern graph \( H \) has a low treewidth, the induced copies of \( H \) in \( G \) can be counted in time \( f(d, k) \cdot \tilde{O}(n^{\tau(H)}) \), where \( \tau(H) \) is called the DAG-treewidth of \( H \) [1]. This approach outperforms classical cubic-time algorithms for sufficiently sparse graphs by making the complexity dependent on the graph's degeneracy and the structure of the pattern graph, rather than solely on its size. For example, practical applications include network motif discovery in biological networks where the networks are typically sparse and have well-defined motifs of interest.

**2. Tree Decompositions and Treewidth**[6]
Another important parameter that improves the efficiency of subgraph counting is treewidth. For graphs with bounded treewidth, subgraph counting can be significantly optimized. For example, a novel algorithm uses tree decompositions to count homomorphisms from \( H \) to \( G \) in time \( f(d, k) \cdot √ï(n^{s(H)}) \), where \( s(H) \) is an associated measure called source-treewidth [2]. This method exploits the decompositional structure of the pattern graph to achieve better efficiency compared to traditional methods in certain sparsity conditions. This approach is particularly useful in computational chemistry for counting specific molecular substructures within larger molecular graphs.

**3. Graphlet Counting** 

[11]


Graphlets are small, connected, non-isomorphic subgraphs used to characterize the local structure of larger networks. Efficient algorithms for counting specific types of \( k \)-node graphlets (e.g., triangles, 4-node motifs) have been developed. For instance, optimized algorithms for counting 3- and 4-node graphlets can run in linear and near-linear time for graphs with bounded degeneracy, significantly faster than cubic time [11]. These algorithms leverage combinatorial arguments that relate smaller graphlet counts to larger ones, thus reducing the computation required for larger graphlets. These algorithms have been demonstrated to be practical and scalable, with applications across various domains including biology, where they help in understanding the complex relationships between proteins, and social network analysis, where graphlets are used to uncover hidden social structures.

**4. Approximation and Sampling Methods** [5]. 
Approximation algorithms that use sampling techniques provide another avenue for faster subgraph counting. These methods trade off some accuracy for significant gains in computational speed. For example, a sampling-based algorithm achieves estimates for 4-vertex subgraphs with less than 1% error while being orders of magnitude faster than exact enumeration methods [5]. These methods often employ random walks or edge sampling strategies to approximate the count of subgraphs, such as the Path Sampling method, which is extremely fast even on very large graphs. Such techniques have proven effective for large-scale graphs where precise counting would be computationally prohibitive. For instance, in large-scale social networks and web graphs, these methods can quickly identify prevalent substructures, facilitating rapid analysis and visualization.

**5. k-Core Decompositions** [7]
The k-core of a graph is its maximal subgraph in which each vertex has at least degree \( k \). The core number of a vertex is the highest \( k \) for which the vertex belongs to the k-core. Algorithms that utilize k-core decompositions can efficiently narrow down the graph to its densest parts, enabling faster counting of subgraphs within these dense regions [7]. This method optimizes counting by focusing on substructures where the density is highest, thus significantly reducing the search space. This technique is particularly useful in network robustness studies where identifying core structures can help understand critical nodes and potential vulnerabilities.

These properties and parameterizations enable the development of advanced, efficient subgraph counting algorithms tailored to specific graph structures and sparsity, significantly enhancing performance beyond the classic cubic time complexity [1].

The computational complexity of subgraph counting can be significant, especially for large graphs and larger subgraph sizes. The challenge lies in the combinatorial explosion of potential subgraphs to be counted. For instance, enumerating all k-vertex subgraphs can have a time complexity of \(O(n^k)\), where \(n\) is the number of vertices in the graph, making it infeasible for large \(k\) [5][6]. ### Limitations and Challenges

Counting subgraphs is a fundamental problem in the analysis of complex networks and has significant theoretical and practical importance. In practice, subgraph counts are widely used to analyze real-world graphs, such as those representing telecommunication networks, biological structures, and social interactions [1]. For example, networks from various scientific domains like biochemistry, neurobiology, and ecology exhibit different small subgraph patterns, which can uncover fundamental building blocks of these networks [1].

Despite its importance, subgraph counting faces substantial challenges. One major issue is the computational complexity, as enumerating all induced subgraphs of size \( k \) in a graph with \( n \) vertices may require a running time of \( O(n^k) \), making it infeasible for large graphs [5].

While there are many algorithms developed to tackle subgraph counting, such as symmetry compression methods and heuristic graph isomorphism algorithms, these methods can still be computationally intensive, especially for large networks [2]. Moreover, designing efficient exact and approximate sampling algorithms remains a priority to manage the combinatorial explosion as the size of subgraphs increases [4].



Despite their broad utility, current subgraph counting algorithms face several limitations and challenges [1]. 

1. **Scalability**: Many subgraph counting algorithms struggle with scalability, especially when dealing with large networks with millions or billions of nodes and edges. The computational complexity often grows exponentially with the size of the subgraph, making it infeasible for large-scale applications [6][12].

2. **Accuracy**: Approximation methods are often employed to handle large datasets, but these can introduce errors and may not always guarantee accurate counts, which can be critical in sensitive applications like fraud detection and biological research [7].

3. **Complex Network Structures**: Real-world networks often exhibit complex structures like overlapping communities, hierarchical organization, and varying levels of sparsity and density. These characteristics can complicate subgraph counting algorithms, which may need to be specialized or adapted to handle specific types of networks robustly [9][11].

4. **Resource Intensity**: Subgraph counting can be resource-intensive, requiring significant computational power and memory, which limits its applicability in resource-constrained environments [13].

Theories of distributed cognition have significantly influenced the design of features in social computing systems by providing a framework that emphasizes the importance of understanding cognitive processes as distributed across individuals, tools, and environments [1]. This perspective has led to the development of systems that support collective intelligence, enhance coordination, and facilitate shared understanding among users [4].

One of the central tenets of distributed cognition is the idea that cognitive processes are not confined to an individual's mind but are distributed across people and artifacts in the environment. This concept has guided the design of social computing systems to support collaborative work and knowledge sharing. For example, the design of the Wikipedia collaborative platform exemplifies how distributed cognition can inform the creation of tools that enable collective knowledge construction. The cognitive organization that occurs within social interactions on Wikipedia serves as a catalyst for intelligence to emerge on a group level, facilitating the collaborative editing and refinement of articles [4]. A process model developed as part of the analysis shows how collaborative knowledge construction in Wikipedia is achieved, providing empirical support for this approach. Specifically, Wikipedia employs mechanisms such as history tracking, discussion pages, and revision control, which collectively support distributed cognitive processes by enabling users to trace changes, engage in dialogue, and collaboratively refine content.

Additionally, distributed cognition emphasizes the importance of external representations and tools in supporting cognitive processes. This has informed the design of information visualization (InfoVis) systems, where visual tools are used to externalize knowledge, organize work, and create new demands for problem-solving [7]. By providing users with visual aids to interact with and interpret complex data, these systems extend cognitive processes beyond the individual and into the environment, facilitating better decision-making and problem-solving. A real-life scenario described in the research highlights the impact of InfoVis systems designed using the distributed cognition framework, demonstrating their effectiveness in enhancing cognitive processes. For example, InfoVis systems often incorporate interactive dashboards and data manipulation tools that allow users to explore and contextualize large datasets, thereby supporting distributed cognition by making data insights more accessible and actionable. These systems address specific tasks such as trend analysis, data correlation, and pattern recognition, which are critical for informed decision-making in domains like healthcare, finance, and education.

The integration of distributed cognition with distributed leadership theories has also led to the development of tools that support online creative collaboration. For instance, Pipeline, a collaboration tool designed for Newgrounds, redistributes leadership roles among team members to reduce the burden on individual leaders. This tool was developed based on the understanding that effective collaboration requires both technological support and the distribution of cognitive and leadership tasks across the group [10]. Pipeline incorporates features such as task delegation, progress tracking, and communication facilitation to ensure that leadership responsibilities are shared evenly. A case study of a six-week, 30-artist collaboration called Holiday Flood showed how Pipeline supported redistributed leadership, providing empirical evidence of its effectiveness. In these systems, leadership and cognitive responsibilities are designed to be fluid, adapting to the needs of the project and team dynamics, which ensures more balanced participation and reduces bottlenecks associated with conventional leadership models. Specifically, these tools address the challenges of project coordination, task prioritization, and resource allocation in creative projects, enhancing productivity and project completion rates.

Furthermore, the principles of distributed cognition have been applied to the design of knowledge management systems in organizations. By acknowledging the unique properties and processes of distributed human-computer information systems, researchers have developed prototypes that enhance organizational memory and knowledge management. These systems are designed to capture and support the dynamic interactions between people and their environment, facilitating effective communication and coordination [14]. For example, such systems often include features like shared repositories, collaboration tools, and automated knowledge capture mechanisms. An empirical study combining insights from multiple case studies further validates the benefits of these systems in achieving effective design outcomes. These systems address tasks such as information retrieval, knowledge dissemination, and collaborative problem-solving within organizations, thus improving efficiency and innovation.

In the context of education, distributed cognition has informed the design of collaborative learning environments. For example, research on collaborative computer science learning has shown how distributed cognition can be used to analyze and improve interaction and learning within groups of students. By leveraging the knowledge of individuals and the affordances of various tools, these learning environments support the collective accomplishment of complex tasks [2]. Qualitative case study analysis of middle school students programming computer music provides concrete evidence of the benefits of applying distributed cognition theories to educational settings. The study highlights methods such as the use of shared programming interfaces, collaborative problem-solving tasks, and iterative project-based learning to optimize the learning experience through distributed cognitive processes. These designs address educational tasks such as concept understanding, skill development, and collaborative project execution, thereby enriching the overall learning process.

Another noteworthy example is the design of social media platforms. Social media features such as tagging, sharing, commenting, and liking are influenced by distributed cognition theories [4]. These features enable users to collectively process and disseminate information efficiently. For instance, on platforms like Twitter and Facebook, users leverage hashtags to categorize content and facilitate the discovery of information by others [4]. These tagging and categorization systems allow cognitive processes to be distributed among users, thereby enhancing the collective processing and retrieval of information [4]. Social media systems address tasks such as information dissemination, community engagement, and trend analysis, facilitating more effective communication and interaction among users [4].

However, the application of distributed cognition theories to social computing systems also faces several challenges and limitations. One significant challenge is ensuring the seamless integration of human and technological components within a distributed cognitive system. This involves addressing issues related to usability, interoperability, and the cognitive load imposed on users by complex interfaces and functionalities [14]. Additionally, while distributed cognition frameworks encourage collaborative work and knowledge sharing, they may inadvertently lead to issues of cognitive overload where users are overwhelmed by the amount of information and interactions required to participate effectively [2]. This necessitates careful design considerations to balance the distribution of cognitive tasks and prevent user fatigue [2]. Moreover, the reliance on external representations and tools can introduce vulnerabilities, such as system failures or security breaches, which can disrupt distributed cognitive processes and affect overall system performance [11].

Overall, the theories of distributed cognition have provided a robust framework for designing social computing systems that facilitate collaboration, enhance cognitive processes, and support the collective intelligence of groups [0]. By focusing on the distribution of cognitive processes across individuals and artifacts, these systems enable users to interact more effectively, share knowledge, and achieve coordinated outcomes while also considering the potential limitations and challenges to ensure optimal design and functionality [1]. The impact of these theories is evident in various domains, from collaborative work environments to education and social media, demonstrating their versatility and relevance in addressing complex cognitive and social tasks [2].
